Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do the neutrinos reach Earth before the photons do?
Options: A. Photons do not travel straight to Earth, B. We can see photons better than neutrinos, C. Neutrinos travel faster than light, D. Not enough photons are expelled
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the average frequency of supernovae per year in a galaxy the size and age of the Milky Way? Options: A. 1-5 years, B. 10-20 years, C. 25-50 years, D. 100-200 years Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary challenge in observing a supernova from its first violent moments? Options: A. The distance between the star and Earth, B. The speed of light, C. The need to have telescopes focused on the right star at the right time, D. The lack of technology to detect neutrinos Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of particles travel faster than photons in a supernova? Options: A. Electrons, B. Protons, C. Neutrinos, D. Photons Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main difference between Type 1 and Type 2 supernovae? Options: A. The type of star that explodes, B. The amount of energy released, C. The cause of the explosion (runaway nuclear reaction vs. gravitational forces), D. The distance from Earth Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary component of the energy released in a Type 2 supernova? Options: A. Photons (light), B. Neutrinos, C. Matter, D. A combination of photons and neutrinos Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the Supernova Early Warning System (SNEWS) designed to detect? Options: A. Visible light from supernovae, B. Neutrinos from supernovae, C. Both visible light and neutrinos from supernovae, D. Other types of celestial events Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long does it typically take for neutrinos to reach Earth from a supernova? Options: A. A few minutes, B. Several hours, C. Several days, D. Several weeks Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the purpose of the SNEWS central computer in New York? Options: A. To analyze data from neutrino detectors, B. To send alerts to astronomers and scientists, C. To coordinate the response to a supernova alert, D. To store data from neutrino detectors Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the last supernova that sent detectable neutrinos to Earth? Options: A. In 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula, B. In 1999 in the Milky Way, C. In 2007 in a nearby galaxy, D. In 2017 in a distant galaxy Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main benefit of the SNEWS system for astronomers and scientists? Options: A. To detect supernovae earlier than before, B. To study the properties of supernovae, C. To coordinate the response to a supernova alert, D. To predict the occurrence of supernovae Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 is not an exact match, it is the closest in terms of question intent and content. The ground truth MCQ asks why neutrinos reach Earth before photons, and the correct answer is that photons do not travel straight to Earth. Question 3 asks what type of particles travel faster than photons in a supernova, but this is a misconception, as neutrinos do not travel faster than photons. However, according to the transcript, neutrinos do reach Earth before photons because they take a more direct route. 

A more accurate generated MCQ would be one that asks why neutrinos reach Earth before photons, with options that include the correct answer: that neutrinos take a more direct route or that photons do not travel straight to Earth. However, among the provided generated MCQs, Question 3 is the closest match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Metals heavier than what element are formed in supernovae?
Options: A. Copper, B. Silver, C. Nickel, D. Gold
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

The need to have telescopes focused on the right star at the right time, D. The lack of technology to detect neutrinos Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of energy from a supernova explosion is expelled as neutrinos?
Options: A. 1, B. 90, C. 99, D. 10
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the average frequency of supernovae per year in a galaxy the size and age of the Milky Way? Options: A. 1-5 years, B. 10-20 years, C. 25-50 years, D. 100-200 years Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary challenge in observing a supernova from its first violent moments? Options: A. The distance between the star and Earth, B. The speed of light, C. The need to have telescopes focused on the right star at the right time, D. The lack of technology to detect neutrinos Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of particles travel faster than photons in a supernova? Options: A. Electrons, B. Protons, C. Neutrinos, D. Photons Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main difference between Type 1 and Type 2 supernovae? Options: A. The type of star that explodes, B. The amount of energy released, C. The cause of the explosion (runaway nuclear reaction vs. gravitational forces), D. The distance from Earth Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary component of the energy released in a Type 2 supernova? Options: A. Photons (light), B. Neutrinos, C. Matter, D. A combination of photons and neutrinos Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the Supernova Early Warning System (SNEWS) designed to detect? Options: A. Visible light from supernovae, B. Neutrinos from supernovae, C. Both visible light and neutrinos from supernovae, D. Other types of celestial events Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long does it typically take for neutrinos to reach Earth from a supernova? Options: A. A few minutes, B. Several hours, C. Several days, D. Several weeks Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the purpose of the SNEWS central computer in New York? Options: A. To analyze data from neutrino detectors, B. To send alerts to astronomers and scientists, C. To coordinate the response to a supernova alert, D. To store data from neutrino detectors Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the last supernova that sent detectable neutrinos to Earth? Options: A. In 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula, B. In 1999 in the Milky Way, C. In 2007 in a nearby galaxy, D. In 2017 in a distant galaxy Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main benefit of the SNEWS system for astronomers and scientists? Options: A. To detect supernovae earlier than before, B. To study the properties of supernovae, C. To coordinate the response to a supernova alert, D. To predict the occurrence of supernovae Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is the primary component of the energy released in a Type 2 supernova? 

Although the wording is not identical, the intent of the question is similar, and the correct answer can be inferred from the options provided. The ground truth MCQ asks about the percentage of energy expelled as neutrinos, while Question 5 asks about the primary component of the energy released. However, according to the transcript, in Type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy consists of photons, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos. Therefore, the primary component of the energy released is indeed neutrinos, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A supernova is defined as _____.
Options: A. Meteor, B. Satellite crash, C. Planet explosion, D. Death of a star
Correct Option: D

Just now, somewhere in the universe,

and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out

its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star

to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive

that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction

and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The three indices of the fraud triangle are pressure, opportunity and _____.
Options: A. Critical thinking, B. Rationalization, C. Justification, D. Validation
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to the estimated total amount of money lost to fraud in 2013. Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the model that shows three conditions that make fraud likely? Options: A. The Fraud Triangle, B. The Crime Model, C. The Susceptibility Model, D. The Risk Assessment Model Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is one of the three conditions that make fraud likely, according to the Fraud Triangle? Options: A. Opportunity, B. Pressure, C. Rationalization, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a situation where pressure may motivate someone to engage in fraud? Options: A. A sudden job loss, B. An illness in the family, C. A personal debt, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is an example of a tool that may enable someone to commit and conceal fraud? Options: A. Corporate credit cards, B. Internal company data, C. Control over the budget, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is an example of a type of fraud that may not even register as such to the perpetrator? Options: A. Embezzlement, B. Pyramid schemes, C. Fudging time sheets, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: In 2003, which Italian dairy food giant went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements? Options: A. Parmalat, B. Nestle, C. Danone, D. Unilever Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who was the City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois, who embezzled over 53 million dollars? Options: A. Rita Crundwell, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Donald Cressey, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one of the reasons why Rita Crundwell may have felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle? Options: A. Her position as City Comptroller, B. The notoriety her winnings brought to the city, C. Her position as a leading quarter horse breeder, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the transcript, who are often the victims of fraud? Options: A. Corporations and civic institutions, B. Real people, C. The employees of Parmalat, D. All of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What is one of the three conditions that make fraud likely, according to the Fraud Triangle? Options: A. Opportunity, B. Pressure, C. Rationalization, D. All of the above.

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it asks about the conditions that make fraud likely, according to the Fraud Triangle. The options provided in Question 3 include all three conditions mentioned in the ground truth MCQ (pressure, opportunity, and rationalization), although the correct option is not specified.

However, a more specific match would be a generated MCQ that asks about the third condition of the Fraud Triangle, which is rationalization. Unfortunately, such a specific question is not available among the generated MCQs.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fraud is a $_____ problem.
Options: A. 2.5 billion, B. 3.7 trillion, C. 100 billion, D. 10 trillion
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to the estimated total amount of money lost to fraud in 2013. Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the model that shows three conditions that make fraud likely? Options: A. The Fraud Triangle, B. The Crime Model, C. The Susceptibility Model, D. The Risk Assessment Model Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is one of the three conditions that make fraud likely, according to the Fraud Triangle? Options: A. Opportunity, B. Pressure, C. Rationalization, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a situation where pressure may motivate someone to engage in fraud? Options: A. A sudden job loss, B. An illness in the family, C. A personal debt, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is an example of a tool that may enable someone to commit and conceal fraud? Options: A. Corporate credit cards, B. Internal company data, C. Control over the budget, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is an example of a type of fraud that may not even register as such to the perpetrator? Options: A. Embezzlement, B. Pyramid schemes, C. Fudging time sheets, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: In 2003, which Italian dairy food giant went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements? Options: A. Parmalat, B. Nestle, C. Danone, D. Unilever Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who was the City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois, who embezzled over 53 million dollars? Options: A. Rita Crundwell, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Donald Cressey, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one of the reasons why Rita Crundwell may have felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle? Options: A. Her position as City Comptroller, B. The notoriety her winnings brought to the city, C. Her position as a leading quarter horse breeder, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the transcript, who are often the victims of fraud? Options: A. Corporations and civic institutions, B. Real people, C. The employees of Parmalat, D. All of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the wording of the question is slightly different, the intent and content of the question are the same, which is to ask about the estimated total amount of money lost to fraud. The options also include the correct answer, which is 3.7 trillion dollars.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 4

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
Options: A. -9.8 meters per second squared, B. -4.9 meters per second squared, C. -32 meters per second squared, D. -16 meters per second squared
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the human limit for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave the ground to when they touch down again? Options: A. 2 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 3 seconds, D. 5 seconds Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the force that makes it hard to stay in the air longer? Options: A. Air resistance, B. Gravity, C. Wind, D. Friction Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the acceleration of Earth's gravity in meters per second squared? Options: A. 5 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 10 meters per second squared, D. 12 meters per second squared Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the equation that models hang time, according to the transcript? Options: A. Height = initial height + initial velocity, B. Height = initial height + initial velocity * time, C. Height = initial height + initial velocity * time + (1/2) * g * time^2, D. Height = initial height - initial velocity * time Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which is a possible equation that could model the relationship between height and hang time for someone on Venus?
Options: A. h=8.87t^2-4.5t, B. h=-8.87t^2+4.5t, C. h=-4.44t^2+4.5t, D. h=4.44t^2-4.5t
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Gluten can be found in which type of grains?
Options: A. Wheat, B. Rye, C. Barley, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in wheat, rye, and barley, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods, D. A type of fiber found in wheat and other grains Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is celiac disease? Options: A. A condition in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage of the lining of the small intestine, B. A condition in which a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins, C. A condition in which a person experiences painful gut symptoms and suffers from fatigue, brain fog, and joint pain, D. A condition in which a person has a gluten-free diet Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. A gluten-containing diet, B. A wheat-free diet, C. A gluten-free diet, D. A fiber-rich diet Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A condition in which a person has a wheat allergy, B. A condition in which a person has celiac disease, C. A condition in which a person experiences symptoms when they eat foods with gluten, but does not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy, D. A condition in which a person has a gluten-free diet Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the nocebo effect? Options: A. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms improve when they believe they are taking a treatment, B. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms worsen when they believe they are taking a treatment, C. A phenomenon in which a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does, D. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms are caused by a specific food Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the opposite of the placebo effect? Options: A. The nocebo effect, B. The wheat intolerance effect, C. The gluten sensitivity effect, D. The celiac disease effect Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the sugars found in wheat and other foods that some people are sensitive to? Options: A. Fructans, B. Gliadins, C. Glutenins, D. Wheatens Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the effect of fructans on the human intestine? Options: A. They are broken down and absorbed by the small intestine, B. They are fermented by bacteria in the large intestine, producing short-chain fatty acids and gases, C. They are excreted in the urine, D. They are stored in the liver Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the estimated prevalence of non-celiac gluten sensitivity in the general population? Options: A. 1 in 100 to 200 people, B. 1 in 10 to 20 people, C. 1 in 50 to 100 people, D. Unclear Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the best name for the condition in which people experience symptoms when they eat wheat and other grains, but do not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy? Options: A. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity, B. Wheat intolerance, C. Gluten sensitivity, D. Celiac disease Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, the most similar generated MCQ would be:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: An inherited disease in which eating gluten inflames and damages the lining of the small intenstine is called:
Options: A. A wheat allergy, B. Anaphylaxis, C. Celiac disease, D. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in wheat, rye, and barley, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods, D. A type of fiber found in wheat and other grains Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is celiac disease? Options: A. A condition in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage of the lining of the small intestine, B. A condition in which a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins, C. A condition in which a person experiences painful gut symptoms and suffers from fatigue, brain fog, and joint pain, D. A condition in which a person has a gluten-free diet Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. A gluten-containing diet, B. A wheat-free diet, C. A gluten-free diet, D. A fiber-rich diet Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A condition in which a person has a wheat allergy, B. A condition in which a person has celiac disease, C. A condition in which a person experiences symptoms when they eat foods with gluten, but does not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy, D. A condition in which a person has a gluten-free diet Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the nocebo effect? Options: A. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms improve when they believe they are taking a treatment, B. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms worsen when they believe they are taking a treatment, C. A phenomenon in which a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does, D. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms are caused by a specific food Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the opposite of the placebo effect? Options: A. The nocebo effect, B. The wheat intolerance effect, C. The gluten sensitivity effect, D. The celiac disease effect Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the sugars found in wheat and other foods that some people are sensitive to? Options: A. Fructans, B. Gliadins, C. Glutenins, D. Wheatens Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the effect of fructans on the human intestine? Options: A. They are broken down and absorbed by the small intestine, B. They are fermented by bacteria in the large intestine, producing short-chain fatty acids and gases, C. They are excreted in the urine, D. They are stored in the liver Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the estimated prevalence of non-celiac gluten sensitivity in the general population? Options: A. 1 in 100 to 200 people, B. 1 in 10 to 20 people, C. 1 in 50 to 100 people, D. Unclear Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the best name for the condition in which people experience symptoms when they eat wheat and other grains, but do not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy? Options: A. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity, B. Wheat intolerance, C. Gluten sensitivity, D. Celiac disease Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What is celiac disease? 

However, the options provided in Question 2 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A more accurate match would be a generated MCQ that specifically asks about an "inherited disease" and has options that include "celiac disease" as the correct answer.

Since there isn't an exact match, I will choose the closest match based on the content. 

The closest match is Question 2.

However, I must note that the generated MCQs do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A more accurate match would be a generated MCQ that specifically asks about an "inherited disease" and has options that include "celiac disease" as the correct answer.

the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When a person believes something will cause problems and because of that belief, it does, it is called:
Options: A. Bad press, B. A placebo effect, C. Sensitivity, D. Nocebo effect
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in wheat, rye, and barley, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods, D. A type of fiber found in wheat and other grains Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is celiac disease? Options: A. A condition in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage of the lining of the small intestine, B. A condition in which a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins, C. A condition in which a person experiences painful gut symptoms and suffers from fatigue, brain fog, and joint pain, D. A condition in which a person has a gluten-free diet Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. A gluten-containing diet, B. A wheat-free diet, C. A gluten-free diet, D. A fiber-rich diet Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A condition in which a person has a wheat allergy, B. A condition in which a person has celiac disease, C. A condition in which a person experiences symptoms when they eat foods with gluten, but does not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy, D. A condition in which a person has a gluten-free diet Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the nocebo effect? Options: A. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms improve when they believe they are taking a treatment, B. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms worsen when they believe they are taking a treatment, C. A phenomenon in which a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does, D. A phenomenon in which a person's symptoms are caused by a specific food Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the opposite of the placebo effect? Options: A. The nocebo effect, B. The wheat intolerance effect, C. The gluten sensitivity effect, D. The celiac disease effect Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the sugars found in wheat and other foods that some people are sensitive to? Options: A. Fructans, B. Gliadins, C. Glutenins, D. Wheatens Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the effect of fructans on the human intestine? Options: A. They are broken down and absorbed by the small intestine, B. They are fermented by bacteria in the large intestine, producing short-chain fatty acids and gases, C. They are excreted in the urine, D. They are stored in the liver Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the estimated prevalence of non-celiac gluten sensitivity in the general population? Options: A. 1 in 100 to 200 people, B. 1 in 10 to 20 people, C. 1 in 50 to 100 people, D. Unclear Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the best name for the condition in which people experience symptoms when they eat wheat and other grains, but do not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy? Options: A. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity, B. Wheat intolerance, C. Gluten sensitivity, D. Celiac disease Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

The correct option in Question 5 (Option C) is also identical to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (Option D).
